text: Picklesburgh is Pittsburgh’s annual pickle-themed food festival, celebrating all things pickled. The event is held in the Golden Triangle area of downtown Pittsburgh.
The 2025 Picklesburgh Festival has concluded, and organizers thanked visitors for attending. It will return next year, with updates available via subscription.

Picklesburgh has been named USA Today’s 2025 Readers’ Choice Best Specialty Food Festival. This marks the fourth time the festival has won the award, reclaiming the title after finishing second last year.
Picklesburgh is produced and managed by a local Pittsburgh organization. The event features pickle-based foods, drinks, and merchandise, attracting thousands of visitors each year.

Picklesburgh is Pittsburgh’s annual destination for all things pickled. The festival has been voted the #1 Specialty Food Festival in the United States four times by readers of USA Today. It features handcrafted food and artisan drinks using pickled ingredients from local chefs, restaurants, and vendors, along with pickle-themed snacks, merchandise, contests, and live entertainment in Downtown Pittsburgh.
The 2025 Picklesburgh Festival will take place from Friday, July 11 to Sunday, July 13, 2025. Festival hours are: Friday and Saturday from Noon to 10 p.m., and Sunday from Noon to 6 p.m.

Picklesburgh is held across several Downtown Pittsburgh locations, including the 6th and 7th Street Bridges, Allegheny Landing, Fort Duquesne Boulevard, PPG Plaza, Market Square, 6th Street, and the Heinz Hall Garden View.
Admission to Picklesburgh is always free and no tickets are required. The event is primarily cashless, and attendees must be 21 or older to consume or purchase alcohol, with valid ID required.

Visitors can find convenient parking throughout Downtown Pittsburgh. Real-time parking availability is provided at https://parkpgh.org/. To avoid traffic, guests can also park across town or use public transportation. More details are available under 'Getting Here' on the festival website.

Nearby accommodations include several hotels in Downtown Pittsburgh. The Renaissance Pittsburgh Hotel offers an exclusive 'Picklesburgh Package' with festival merchandise and special deals. Rooms are expected to sell out quickly, so early reservations via Marriott.com are recommended. Visitors may also stay outside Downtown and use public transportation to reach the event.

The 2025 Picklesburgh Festival thanks its sponsors for their support. The presenting partner is The Kraft Heinz Company, the third-largest food and beverage company in North America and fifth-largest worldwide. Website: https://www.kraftheinzcompany.com/

2025 Presenting Partner – Dill-Cathlon: Chicken of the Sea. Their Wild Caught Light Tuna Packet with McCormick® Dill Tuna Salad is featured as part of Picklesburgh’s Dill-Cathlon. Website: https://chickenofthesea.com/

2025 Presenting Partner – Music Stage: Turner’s is the Official Iced Tea of Picklesburgh. They offer a Pickled Lemonade made with Picklexir from Pittsburgh Pickle Co., available exclusively at the festival. Website: www.drinkturners.com
2025 Presenting Partner – Pickle Riding: Pella Windows & Doors, rated #1 by homeowners in Pittsburgh for attention to detail. Website: www.pella.com/pittsburgh
2025 Picklesburgh Beer Partner: Frank B. Fuhrer Wholesale Company, located in Pittsburgh’s South Side, is the 20th largest beer wholesaler in the U.S. Website: https://fuhrerwholesale.com/
2025 Presenting Partner – Lil’ Gherkins KidsPlay: Chick-fil-A, known for its quality food and fresh ingredients, is featured as a family-friendly partner. Website: www.chick-fil-a.com/

2025 Presenting Partner – Merchandise Bags: FNB (First National Bank) provides a full range of commercial and consumer banking, wealth management, and mobile banking services. Website: www.fnb-online.com
2025 Exhibitor: I LOVE NY, New York State’s official tourism campaign, promotes New York’s attractions, cuisine, craft beverages, and festivals. Website: www.iloveny.com
2025 Exhibitor: Jenny Lee Swirl Bread, known for 'The World’s Best Cinnamon Swirl Bread'. Website: www.jennyleeswirlbread.com

2025 Exhibitor: Mancini’s Bakery features Pepperoni Rolls & PGH Roll made with Isaly’s Chipped Ham, Heinz Pickle, Mozzarella Cheese, and Mancini’s Rustic Italian dough. Website: www.MancinisBakery.com
2025 Band Sponsor: The Pennsylvania Lottery supports programs benefiting older Pennsylvanians. Website: https://www.palottery.pa.gov/
2025 Exhibitor: NRG, a leading North American energy and home services company focused on smart home and business solutions. Website: https://www.nrg.com/
2025 Exhibitor: Xfinity supports Picklesburgh as a connectivity partner, offering high-speed internet and mobile services with nationwide 5G coverage. Website: https://www.xfinity.com/
2025 Sponsor – Wristbands: Dugan & Associates, serving the legal needs of Western Pennsylvania since 1988. Website: https://www.dugan-associates.com/
2025 Presenting Partner – Pickle Juice Drinking Competition: Pittsburgh Pickle Company, dedicated to crafting high-quality pickle products. Website: https://pittsburghpickle.com/
2025 Presenting Partner – Bobbing for Pickles Competition: KMG & Sons Law, a professional firm combining the scale of a large firm with personal service. Website: https://www.kmgslaw.com/

2025 Presenting Partner – Li’l Gherkins KidsPlay: The Pittsburgh Pirates, the city’s professional baseball team with a rich history of championships and legendary players. Website: https://www.mlb.com/pirates

2025 Exhibitor: The Original Pickle Shot, a naturally flavored vodka made with pickle brine, five-times distilled corn vodka, and no artificial ingredients or sugar. Website: https://www.theoriginalpickleshot.com/
Picklesburgh welcomes future sponsors and exhibitors. Those interested in participating can complete the Sponsor Interest Form on the official website.
Picklesburgh 2025 will take place in Downtown Pittsburgh. A detailed festival map is available online for visitors to view.

Road closures for Picklesburgh 2025 will occur in five phases from Monday, July 7 through Wednesday, July 16, 2025. Phase 1 (July 7–9): Ft. Duquesne Blvd. westbound from 7th St. to Stanwix St., Roberto Clemente Bridge (6th St. Bridge), and Andy Warhol Bridge (7th St. Bridge) closed between Ft. Duquesne Blvd. and Isabella St.
Phase 2 (July 9–11): The same closures as Phase 1 remain, with additional restrictions on 6th St. (Ft. Duquesne Blvd. to Liberty Ave.) and Fourth Ave. (Stanwix St. to Third Ave Garage exit).

Phase 3 (July 11–13): Extended closures include Ft. Duquesne Blvd. (7th St. to Stanwix St.), Roberto Clemente Bridge, Andy Warhol Bridge, 6th St. (Ft. Duquesne Blvd. to Liberty Ave.), Fourth Ave. (Stanwix St. to Third Ave), and Isabella St. (Federal St. to Sandusky St.).

Phase 4 (July 13–14): The same closures continue overnight until Monday morning, July 14, at 9:00 AM. Phase 5 (July 14–16): Ft. Duquesne Blvd. and both bridges remain closed for event teardown. Market Square will also be closed to vehicles: Friday & Saturday 11 AM–11 PM, Sunday 11 AM–7 PM.

Driving detours are established for major routes: Ft. Duquesne Blvd. detour uses 7th St., Penn Ave., Stanwix St., and returns to Ft. Duquesne Blvd. Southbound detour from Downtown to North Shore uses Gen. Robinson St., Anderson St., Penn Ave., and Stanwix St. Northbound detour from North Shore to Downtown uses the 9th St. (Rachel Carson) Bridge and Lacock St. to Federal St.

Parking is available throughout Downtown Pittsburgh. Drivers can check real-time parking at https://parkpgh.org/. Private garages may charge event rates, while Pittsburgh Parking Authority garages generally do not, except for the Sixth & Ft. Duquesne Garage. Recommended garages include Ft. Duquesne & Sixth (PPA), 6th & Penn (iParkit), Third Avenue (PPA), Theater Square (Alco), Smith & Liberty, Oliver, Mellon Square, Wood Allies, Riverfront Center, Etage, North Shore, and Gen Robinson garages.

For cyclists, nearby covered bike parking is available at Theater Square Bike Garage, One PPG Place (temporary racks), Third Ave Garage, Ft. Duquesne & Sixth Garage, Smithfield-Liberty Garage, and Allegheny Landing. A detour route is provided due to the Roberto Clemente Bridge bike lane closure, directing cyclists via the Three Rivers Heritage Trail and Point State Park connections.

Public transit routes operated by Pittsburgh Regional Transit (PRT) will be detoured from July 7 to July 16, 2025, due to bridge and road closures. Affected routes include 1-Freeport Rd, 11-Fineview, 12-McKnight, 13-Bellevue, 15-Charles, 16-Brighton, 17-Shadeland, 2-Mount Royal, 4-Troy Hill, 6-Spring Hill, 7-Spring Garden, 8-Perrysville, and P13-Mount Royal Flyer.

Additional route detours begin July 9 for routes 52L, 53L, 56, 57, and 58, due to Fourth Avenue closures between Stanwix and Wood Streets. Penn Avenue remains open. The 86, 87, 88, and 91 routes will not be detoured but may experience delays.

On Friday, July 11, bus stops at Seventh St. & Penn Ave. and Ft. Duquesne Blvd. & Sixth St. will be missed due to the America’s Mile event. Riders are encouraged to plan for delays and consult PRT’s detour page at www.rideprt.org/Detours/ or contact customer service at 412-442-2000 or @PghTransitCare on X (formerly Twitter).
Picklesburgh 2025 will feature its most ambitious festival footprint yet, expanding across multiple key locations in Downtown Pittsburgh.

The 2025 festival spans two of Pittsburgh’s Sister Bridges—the Roberto Clemente Bridge (6th Street Bridge) and the Andy Warhol Bridge (7th Street Bridge)—as well as Allegheny Landing, Fort Duquesne Boulevard, Sixth Street, Heinz Hall Garden, Market Square, and PPG Plaza.

Key locations in the Picklesburgh 2025 Festival Map: A. PPG Plaza (recommended starting point); B. Market Square; C. Heinz Hall Courtyard & Sixth Street; D. Fort Duquesne Boulevard; E. Sixth Street Bridge (Roberto Clemente Bridge); F. Seventh Street Bridge (Andy Warhol Bridge); G. Isabella Street and Allegheny Landing.
A downloadable and printable full festival map is available online, showing detailed routes, road closures, parking areas, and transportation options.
Picklesburgh is committed to making the festival accessible for all visitors and welcomes feedback or accessibility-related questions via email at pdp@downtownpittsburgh.com.

Wheelchair Access: Picklesburgh is held outdoors on fully paved and navigable surfaces. Guests who require mobility assistance are encouraged to bring personal wheelchairs or scooters, as the festival does not provide rentals or wheelchair services.
Restrooms: Every restroom area at Picklesburgh is equipped with ADA-compliant bathrooms to accommodate guests with disabilities.
Guide Dogs: Service animals and guide dogs are welcome throughout the event. Owners should ensure their service animals are clearly identifiable.
Parking: ADA-accessible parking is available at all nearby garages, offering convenient access to the Picklesburgh festival footprint.
Vendor and Stage Areas: All vendor zones and viewing areas for the music and Dill-Cathlon stages at PPG Plaza are wheelchair accessible, with designated ADA viewing sections.
Maps: Restroom, stage, and vendor locations will be shown on the online festival map, accessible via QR codes placed throughout the event area and at information booths.
Picklesburgh 2025 features a variety of vendors offering dill-icious foods, pickle-themed snacks, craft beverages, and unique merchandise throughout the weekend.

Specialty cocktails are available during happy hour: Friday and Saturday from 3:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m., and Sunday from 12:00 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. Food, beer, and other beverages are served during all festival hours.
The Picklesburgh 2025 Vendor Directory allows visitors to search for vendors by name, booth location, or description. Vendor information is subject to updates at any time.

Taste of Picklesburgh 2025 will take place from Monday, July 7 to Sunday, July 13, 2025. This pre-festival event features pickle-themed food, beverages, and merchandise from 23 participating Downtown Pittsburgh businesses.
During Taste of Picklesburgh, guests who purchase a pickle-themed item will receive a free Heinz Pickle Pin, while supplies last.

Participating Business: Alta Via – Market Square, 2 PPG Place #150. Offerings include Cheese and Charcuterie with Giardiniera, Pasta Salad with Pickled Veggies, Salami, and Mozzarella, and a Dirty Pickle Martini.
The Berg Chicken and Pizza – 4 PPG Place #150. Dishes: Chicken Pickle Pizza, Chicken Pickle Sandwich and Wrap, Fried Pickle Spears with Ranch, and Pickle Vanilla Milkshake.
Café Momentum – 268 Forbes Ave. Offers Polish Pickle Soup, Pickle Pizza, and Pickle Board.
City Works – 2 PPG Place. Features Spicy Pickle-Rita, Pickle Lemonade, Fried Pickles, Pickle-tini, Pulled Pork Sandwich, Cuban Sandwich, and Carolina Fired Chicken Sandwich.
Con Alma – 613 Penn Ave. Offers Samba Song (pickled papaya margarita), Smoke Town (pickled tomatillo martini), and Pickled Sangrita cocktails.
Emerson’s – 435 Market St. Menu includes Pickles & Popcorn, The Big Dill Cocktail, The Brinemaker (spicy pickle shot & Miller High Life).
Forbes Tavern – 310 Forbes Ave. Features Pickled Wings, Pickled Flatbread, Pickle Juice Martini, Pickle-back Shots, and Pickled Scottish Eggs.
Genoa Pizza & Bar – 111 Market St. Offers Pickle Draft Beer, Picklesburgh Pizza, and Picklesburgh Wrap.
Heinz Healey’s – 160 Fifth Ave. Merchandise includes Pickle-print Bucket Hat, 'Paint me green and call me a pickle' T-shirt, and 'I’m kind of a Big Dill' socks.
Howl at the Moon – 125 7th St. Drinks: 'In My Pickle Era' Martini, Poppin’ Pickle Shot, and free pickle stickers during live performances.
Las Velas – 21 Market Square. Menu includes Pickle Margarita, Pickle Taco, and Pickleback Shot.
love, Pittsburgh – 805 Liberty Ave. Sells Dill Pickle Salt, 'Kind Of A Big Dill' greeting card, and Pickle Kreepy Dolls.

Medi’s on Market – 431 Market St. Offers Pickled Pita with customizable protein and pickled toppings (dill tzatziki, spicy pickled pepper relish, pickled onions, and peppers), Pickled Hummus, and Fried Pickles.
The Original Oyster House – 20 Market Sq. Features Pickleback Shot, Spicy Bloody Mary with Gherkin and Shrimp, and Oyster Po’Boy with Fried Pickle Chips.
PAIR Charcuterie – 201 Smithfield St. Offers Pickle Lemonade, Charcuterie Pickle Cups, and Pickle & Cheese Skewers.
Pittsburgh Pop-Up – 25 Market Sq. Serves Pickleback Shots, Fried Pickles, and Pickle Lemonade.
Pizzaiolo Primo – 8 Market Sq. Offers Pickle Pizza, Fried Pickle Spears, and the Dill 75 cocktail.
Redbeard’s on Sixth – 144 Sixth St. Features Pickled Corkscrew Pickle with Coho Cheese on a Stick, Pickleback Bourbon Smash, Pickled Sorbet, and Nachos with Pickle-infused Salsa.
Revel PGH – 242 Forbes Ave. Offers Fried Pickles, Pickle Wings, Ground Beef & Pickle Tacos, Pickle Beer, Pickle-Rita, and Dirty Pickle Martini.
Sawa Wine Bar – 24 Market Sq. Menu includes Pickle Martini, Pickled Marinara and Meatballs, and Pickled Pierogis.

Space Bar – 22 Market Sq. Cocktails: Airglow Martini (dill-infused vodka with pickle brine and dill oil), Dill Void (pickle aquavit cocktail with umami bitters), and Red Dwarf Shot (harissa pickle brine with vodka or whisky).
Whiskey B’s – 5 Market Sq. Offers Pickle Popper Smash Burger, Dill Me Later Cocktail, and a 10th Anniversary Picklesburgh T-Shirt.

The Yard Gastropub – 100 Fifth Ave. Menu includes Spicy Pineapple Pickle Lemonade, Pickle Fries with Buffalo Mustard Aioli, Tony Montana Sandwich, Creamy Dill Pickle Soup, Pick(led) Me Flatbread, and Spear in a Beer (pickle spear in light beer).

Picklesburgh 2025 will feature live, local music throughout the festival, covering multiple genres including pop, rock, country, hip hop, funk, blues, and soul. All performances will take place at Turner’s Music Stage, located at Ft. Duquesne Blvd. and Stanwix Street.

Friday, July 11 – Turner's Music Stage Schedule: 12:00 p.m. Come September (Pop, Rock, Alternative, Country, Hip Hop/RnB); 1:30 p.m. Chris Casalinuovo (Rock, Classical, Blues); 3:00 p.m. Pioneer Records - The Pit Crew (Rock); 4:30 p.m. ALLISSA (Rock); 6:00 p.m. Rocki Boulis (Pop); 7:30 p.m. Megan Paullet and the HR Department (Funk, Pop Rock, Neo Soul); 9:00 p.m. Pickup Line (Pop, Rock, Alternative).

Saturday, July 12 – Turner's Music Stage Schedule: 12:00 p.m. Kelley Jeanne (Country Rock); 1:30 p.m. Glass Caps (Rock); 3:00 p.m. Pioneer Records - Marshall Benton (Alternative, Singer/Songwriter); 4:30 p.m. X-Ray Dead (Rock); 6:00 p.m. Bjorn Jacobsen with Robin Chambers (Delta Gypsygrass); 7:30 p.m. Heatseekers (Pop, Hip Hop/RnB); 9:00 p.m. Polkamaniacs (Polka Rock).

Sunday, July 13 – Turner's Music Stage Schedule: 12:00 p.m. Mark Ferrari (Acoustic Rock); 1:30 p.m. The Right Turn Clyde Experience (Rock); 3:00 p.m. Pioneer Records - Alexis Zak (Rock, Singer/Songwriter); 4:30 p.m. The Appalachian Soul Man Aristotle Jones (Soul).
Additional entertainment activities at Picklesburgh 2025 include the Dill-Cathlon Games, Pickle Riding, and Li’l Gherkins KidsPlay, offering fun for all ages.

Pickle Riding is one of Picklesburgh’s signature attractions, described as a jarring twist on the classic mechanical bull. Participants climb aboard a giant mechanical gherkin that bucks, spins, and wiggles with unpredictable pickle power.
Location: The Pickle Riding attraction is located on Fourth Avenue near PPG Plaza in Downtown Pittsburgh and operates during all festival hours.
Cost: $12 per ride. Tickets can be purchased onsite, and no reservations are required.
Eligibility: Riders must be 18 years or older and are required to sign a waiver upon ticket purchase. All ages are welcome to watch the activity.

Pickle Riding is presented as part of Picklesburgh, Pittsburgh’s nationally recognized #1 Specialty Food Festival by USA Today, known for its pickle-themed food, drinks, contests, and entertainment across Downtown Pittsburgh.

Li’l Gherkins KidsPlay Activity Area at Picklesburgh offers hands-on fun for children, presented by Chick-fil-A and the Pittsburgh Pirates. Kids can make their own pickle button and enjoy pickle-themed carnival games.
Location: The Li’l Gherkins KidsPlay area is located at Allegheny Landing in Downtown Pittsburgh.
Hours: Friday and Saturday from 12:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m., and Sunday from 12:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m.
Activities include a free button-making craft table and carnival games such as pickle jar toss, pickle duck pond, pickle bean bag toss, and pickle derby race.
Cost: Activities under the KidsPlay tent are free. Carnival games cost $2 per play, and tickets can be purchased onsite with no reservation required.

Guidelines: Children (ages 14 and under) must be accompanied by an adult, and adults must be accompanied by a child. One craft per child. No food or beverages are allowed at the craft table, and strollers must be parked outside the tent.
The Dill-Cathlon Games at Picklesburgh 2025 featured multiple pickle-themed competitions. The event has concluded, and congratulations were extended to this year’s champions.

Pickle Juice Drinking Contest – Rules and Regulations: Contestants compete to drink a quart (32 fl oz) of Pittsburgh Pickle Company’s Picklexir as quickly as possible. The fastest participant in each round advances, and the final champion is crowned the 'Duke of Drinking.'

Bobbing for Pickles Contest – Rules and Regulations: Participants may not use their hands. Whoever retrieves the most pickles by weight within 90 seconds using only their mouth wins the round. Finalists compete for the title 'Baron of Bobbing.'

Pickle Eating Contest – Rules and Regulations: Contestants race to eat the most pickles by weight within four minutes. 'Chipmunking' (storing food in the mouth before swallowing) is allowed. The overall winner earns the title 'Earl of Eating.'
Subscribe for Picklesburgh email updates. Required fields for sign-up: Email Address, First Name, Zip Code.

Vendor inquiries: Applications are currently closed. Prospective vendors may complete the Vendor Interest Form to express interest. Note: this form is not a formal application and does not guarantee acceptance.

Performer inquiries: Applications are currently closed. Bands/performers can complete the Performer Interest Form to express interest. Note: completing this form does not guarantee a future booking or an agreement to book.
Media inquiries: Richard Hooper, Vice President, Marketing & Communications, Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership — rhooper@downtownpittsburgh.com.
Media inquiries: Deana Lorenzo, Director of Communications, Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership — dlorenzo@downtownpittsburgh.com.
General inquiries and lost & found: contact the Picklesburgh team via email (general inbox) for comments, questions, and lost-and-found items.

Picklesburgh 2025 | Li’l Gherkins Activity Area | Description: A hands-on kids zone presented by Chick-fil-A and the Pittsburgh Pirates. Children can make their own pickle button and play pickle-themed carnival games. Designed for young pickle lovers to play and create.
Event Schedule | When: Friday & Saturday 12–10 p.m., Sunday 12–6 p.m.
Location: Allegheny Landing | The Li’l Gherkins Activity Area is located within the Allegheny Landing section of Picklesburgh.
Available Activities: Free button-making craft table and carnival games including pickle jar toss, pickle duck pond, pickle bean bag toss, and pickle derby race.
Cost: Activities under the KidsPlay tent are free. Pickle-themed carnival games cost $2 per play. Tickets can be purchased onsite with no reservation required.

Li’l Gherkins Activity Area Guidelines: 1) Children must be accompanied by an adult, and adults must be accompanied by a child. 2) One craft per child, ages 14 and under. 3) No food or beverages at the craft table. 4) Strollers must be parked outside the tent.

Picklesburgh 2025 | Dill-Cathlon Games | Description: Competitive pickle-themed games presented by Chicken of the Sea. The event has ended for 2025. Participants competed in multiple challenges celebrating pickle strength and speed.

2025 Dill-Cathlon Champions: Earl of Eating – 'The Amazing' Joe Oh (devoured all 48 pickles in under 4 minutes); Duke of Drinking – Ryan Thompson, PA (chugged a quart of juice in 30.9 seconds); Baroness of Bobbing – Colleen Krenichich, PA (bobbing 4.7 lbs of pickles).
Event Location: Picklesburgh main stage area | Presenter: Chicken of the Sea.

Contest: Pickle Juice Drinking | Rules: Competitors chug a quart (32 fl oz) of Pittsburgh Pickle Company’s Picklebrine. The fastest finisher wins the round and advances to the championship round for the title 'Duke of Drinking.'
Contest: Bobbing for Pickles | Rules: No hands allowed. Contestants must retrieve pickles by weight within 90 seconds using only their mouth. The winner becomes 'Baron of Bobbing.'
Contest: Pickle Eating | Rules: Contestants eat as many pickles as possible by weight in four minutes. Chipmunking is allowed. The winner earns the title 'Earl of Eating.'

Additional Info: The Dill-Cathlon is a recurring Picklesburgh competition testing pickle enthusiasts’ endurance in drinking, eating, and bobbing events. Winners receive titles and recognition on Picklesburgh’s official stage.

Picklesburgh Dill-Cathlon Games & Festival Overview

**What is Picklesburgh?**  
Picklesburgh is Pittsburgh’s signature celebration of all things **pickled**, voted the **#1 Specialty Food Festival in the Country** four times by the readers of *USA Today*. Held annually in **Downtown Pittsburgh**, the festival features a wide variety of **handcrafted pickled foods**, **artisan cocktails**, and **pickle-themed merchandise** from local chefs and vendors. Visitors can enjoy live entertainment, culinary demos, and fun competitions, all under the city’s iconic **giant flying pickle balloon**.

**Dill-Cathlon Games**  
The Dill-Cathlon is Picklesburgh’s fan-favorite competition series, where participants test their love and endurance for all things briny through a series of pickle-themed contests.

- **Pickle Juice Drinking Contest:**  
  Contestants chug a quart (32 fl oz.) of **Pittsburgh Pickle Company’s Picklexir** as fast as possible. Winners of each round advance to the finals for a chance to earn the title of **Duke of Drinking**.

- **Bobbing for Pickles:**  
  A twist on a classic party game — no hands allowed! Competitors use only their mouths to retrieve as many pickles as possible by weight in 90 seconds. The round winners advance to compete for the title of **Baron of Bobbing**.

- **Pickle Eating Contest:**  
  Contestants race to eat as many pickles (by weight) as possible within four minutes. 'Chipmunking'—holding pickles in the mouth before swallowing—is permitted. The finalist with the strongest stomach is crowned **Earl of Eating**.

**2025 Dill-Cathlon Championship Winners:**  
- **Earl of Eating:** “The Amazing” Joe Oh — *Devoured all 4 lbs of pickles in under 4 minutes!*  
- **Duke of Drinking:** Ryan Thompson, PA — *Chugged a quart of pickle juice in 3.69 seconds!*  
- **Baroness of Bobbing:** Colleen Krenichen, PA — *Bobbing champion with 4.27 lbs of pickles!*

**Festival Highlights:**  
Picklesburgh features:  
- Handcrafted food and **artisan drinks** made with pickled ingredients.  
- **Pickle-themed snacks**, merchandise, and souvenirs.  
- **Live entertainment**, contests, and family-friendly activities set against the scenic backdrop of the **Pittsburgh skyline**.

It’s the ultimate destination for pickle lovers and one of Pittsburgh’s most iconic summer events.

Picklesburgh 2025 – Getting Here & Road Closures

**Festival Location:**  
Picklesburgh 2025 will be held in **Downtown Pittsburgh**, set against the backdrop of the city’s scenic riverfront and bridges. Visitors can view the full festival layout on the official **Festival Map**.

---

**Road Closures:**  
To accommodate festival setup and activities, several major streets and bridges will close in **five phases** throughout the event week:

- **Phase 1 (July 7, 9:00 AM – July 9, 9:00 AM):**  
  - Ft. Duquesne Blvd. (Westbound) from 7th St. to Stanwix St.  
  - Roberto Clemente Bridge (6th St. Bridge) – Ft. Duquesne Blvd. to Isabella St.  
  - Andy Warhol Bridge (7th St. Bridge) – Ft. Duquesne Blvd. to Isabella St.  

- **Phase 2 (July 9, 9:00 AM – July 11, 6:00 PM):**  
  - Ft. Duquesne Blvd. (Westbound) – 7th St. to Stanwix St.  
  - Roberto Clemente Bridge / 6th St. Bridge – Ft. Duquesne Blvd. to Isabella St.  
  - Andy Warhol Bridge / 7th St. Bridge – Ft. Duquesne Blvd. to Isabella St.  
  - 6th St. – Ft. Duquesne Blvd. to Liberty Ave.  
  - Fourth Ave. – Stanwix St. to Third Ave. Garage exit.  
  - Penn Ave. traffic will remain open through the 6th St. intersection.  

- **Phase 3 (July 11, 6:00 PM – July 13, 11:59 PM):**  
  - Same closures as above, plus Isabella St. from Federal St. to Sandusky St.  

- **Phase 4 (July 13, 11:59 PM – July 14, 9:00 AM):**  
  - Continued closures of Ft. Duquesne Blvd. (Westbound), 6th St., Roberto Clemente Bridge, Andy Warhol Bridge, and Fourth Ave.  

- **Phase 5 (July 14 – July 16, 2025):**  
  - Final cleanup and teardown closures along Ft. Duquesne Blvd., 6th St., and the bridges.  

**Market Square Vehicle Closures:**  
- Friday: 11 AM – 11 PM  
- Saturday: 11 AM – 11 PM  
- Sunday: 11 AM – 7 PM  

---

**Driving & Detours:**  
To ease congestion, follow the recommended detour routes:  
- **Ft. Duquesne Blvd. Detour:** Southbound on 7th St. → Right on Penn Ave. → Right on Stanwix St. → Left on Ft. Duquesne Blvd.  
- **Southbound (Downtown → North Shore):** Gen. Robinson St. → Right on Anderson St. → Right on Penn Ave. → Right on Stanwix St. → Ft. Duquesne Blvd.  
- **Northbound (North Shore → Downtown):** Eastbound on Ft. Duquesne Blvd. → Left on Rachel Carson Bridge (9th St. Bridge) → Left on Lacock St. → Federal St.  
- **6th St. Detour:** Eastbound on Ft. Duquesne Blvd. → Right on 7th St. → Right on Liberty Ave. → 6th St.  

---

**Parking Information:**  
- Visit **parkpgh.org** for current garage availability and rates.  
- **Pittsburgh Parking Authority garages** offer standard pricing (except Sixth & Ft. Duquesne Garage).  
- **Private garages** may apply event pricing.  
- All garages remain **open and accessible** during Picklesburgh. Parking near **Market Square** or **central Downtown** is recommended to avoid congestion and closures.

**Detours Starting July 7:**  
- Affected routes: 1-Freeport Road, 11-Fineview, 12-McKnight, 13-Bellevue, 15-Charles, 16-Brighton, 17-Shadeland, 2-Mount Royal, 4-Troy Hill, 6-Spring Hill, 7-Spring Garden, 8-Perrysville, P13-Mount Royal Flyer.  
- **Missed Stop:** Sandusky Street at Isabella Street.

**Detours Starting July 9:**

Riders should allow for **additional travel time** and check **www.rideprt.org/Detours** for complete, up-to-date detour information.

Picklesburgh 2025 – Festival Footprint & Accessibility Information

**Festival Footprint:**  
Picklesburgh 2025 will feature the **largest footprint in the festival’s history**, spanning multiple Downtown Pittsburgh landmarks:  
- **Two of Pittsburgh’s Sister Bridges**  
- **Allegheny Landing**  
- **Fort Duquesne Boulevard**  
- **Sixth Street**  
- **Heinz Hall Garden**  
- **Market Square**  
- **PPG Plaza**  
This expanded layout connects several key Downtown areas, offering visitors more space for food, entertainment, and community events.

---

**Accessibility Information:**  
Picklesburgh is committed to providing an inclusive experience for all festival-goers.  
If you have specific accessibility concerns, contact the organizers at **pdp@downtownpittsburgh.com**.

- **Wheelchair Access:**  
  The entire festival footprint is **fully paved and wheelchair accessible**. Attendees are encouraged to bring their own mobility devices such as wheelchairs or scooters. Please note that **the event does not provide rental or loaner mobility devices**.

- **Restrooms:**  
  Every restroom area within the Picklesburgh footprint includes **ADA-compliant facilities** for accessibility.

- **Guide Dogs & Service Animals:**  
  **Guide dogs and service animals are welcome** throughout the event. Please ensure that service animals are **easily identifiable**.

- **Accessible Parking:**  
  **ADA-accessible parking** is available in all nearby garages, providing convenient routes to the main event area. For additional parking and detour details, visit the **Getting Here** section.

- **Vendor & Stage Access:**  
  All **vendor zones** and **stage viewing areas** are wheelchair accessible. Dedicated **ADA viewing areas** will be available for both the **Music Stage** and **Dill-Cathlon Stage (PPG Plaza)**.

- **Maps & Information Booths:**  
  Visitors can access **interactive maps** showing restrooms, vendors, and stages:  
  - Online via the official Picklesburgh website.  
  - Through **QR codes** displayed around the event.  
  - At **Info Booths** located throughout the festival footprint.

Picklesburgh 2025 – Festival Attractions: Pickle Riding & Li’l Gherkins KidsPlay Area

**Pickle Riding – The Mechanical Pickle Challenge**  
Hold on tight for a *jarring* experience in this pickle-powered twist on the classic mechanical bull! Riders will climb aboard the **giant mechanical gherkin** and test their balance, strength, and sense of humor as it bucks, spins, and wiggles unpredictably.  

- **Location:** Fourth Avenue near **PPG Plaza**  
- **Operating Hours:** During all festival hours  
- **Cost:** $12 per ride (tickets available onsite, no reservations required)  
- **Age Requirement:** Riders must be **18+**  
- **Waiver:** A signed waiver is required upon ticket purchase  
- **Spectators:** All ages are welcome to watch the fun unfold!

---

**Li’l Gherkins KidsPlay Activity Area**  
A family-friendly zone for young pickle lovers to play, create, and laugh! Presented by **Chick-fil-A** and the **Pittsburgh Pirates**, the Li’l Gherkins Activity Area features hands-on activities, crafts, and pickle-themed carnival games.  

- **When:**  
  - Friday & Saturday: 12 PM – 10 PM  
  - Sunday: 12 PM – 6 PM  
- **Where:** **Allegheny Landing**  
- **Activities:**  
  - Free **pickle button-making craft table**  
  - Pickle-themed carnival games:  
    - Pickle Jar Toss  
    - Pickle Duck Pond  
    - Pickle Bean Bag Toss  
    - Pickle Derby Race  
- **Cost:**  
  - **Craft table:** Free  
  - **Carnival games:** $2 per play (tickets available onsite, no reservations required)  

**Li’l Gherkins Area Guidelines:**  
- Children (“li’l gherkins”) must be **accompanied by an adult**, and adults must be **accompanied by a child**.  
- **One craft per child (ages 14 and under).**  
- **No food or beverages** at the craft table.  
- Please **park strollers outside** the tent area.
